problem.h2: A Bead on a Wire- conceptual
problem.p: A bead of mass m can slide without friction on a double-curved wire. Both curve portions consist on a section of a circle, the first one, of radius r, is contained in the y-z plane and the second one, of radius R, is contained in the x-y plane (z=0). The two curved sections are connected by a straight wire parallel to the y-axis. The bead is released from a height z = H. The goal of the problem is to find the force exerted by the wire on the bead at point Q in the second curve.
Which of the following strategies could you employ to solve this problem?

choicegroup.choice: Use conservation of mechanical energy of the bead-earth system between points H and Q to find the velocity of the bead at Q, and then use \(\vec{F}\) = m\(\vec{a}\) of the bead at point Q to find the normal force from the wire.
Use conservation of kinetic energy of the bead between points H and Q to find the velocity of the bead at Q, and then use centripetal acceleration to find the normal force on the bead from the wire.

Use conservation of momentum of the bead-wire system between points H and Q to find the final velocity, and then use the conservation of kinetic energy to find the work done by non-conservative forces. Use this work to find the force of the wire of the bead.

Use conservation of momentum of the wire-bead system between points H and Q to find the velocity of the bead at point Q, and then use centripetal acceleration to find the normal force of the wire on the bead.
